title: When disk cache and remote cache are both enabled, not all test logs are uploaded to the remote cache

labels.name: P2
labels.description: We'll consider working on this in future. (Assignee optional)

labels.name: team-Remote-Exec
labels.description: Issues and PRs for the Execution (Remote) team

body:
### Description of the bug:


This should be a pretty generic bug since I've reproduced this on at least 3 different bazel repos on bazel 6.4 and 7.0 and on 3 different remote cache implementations (bazel-remote, buildbuddy, and buildbarn).

Essentially, if you have disk cache enabled with `build --disk_cache=/some/path` and `--remote_cache=grpcs://myserver` not all test logs are uploaded to the remote cache `myserver`. However, if you run bazel test a second time (all tests should be cached, so this is actually a no-op), all the test logs get uploaded then. This assigns a new invocation, however, since the shas of the cached tests are the same, the old invocation's test logs get populated too.

By "not all logs are uploaded", I mean that some logs are uploaded successfully, but others are not even attempted to be uploaded (therefore the bazel timeout and retry options have no effect). I haven't been able to find a correlation between which logs are uploaded and which are not. 

If I remove the `--disk_cache=` arg, all the logs are uploaded on the first try.

### Which category does this issue belong to?


Remote caching

### What's the simplest, easiest way to reproduce this bug? Please provide a minimal example if possible.


`bazel test --disk_cache=~/.cache/bazel --remote_cache=grpc://localhost:9089 --bes_backend=<something> --noremote_upload_local_results --experimental_build_event_upload_max_retries=10 --remote_retries=10 --remote_timeout=1h //...`

I haven't tested without the bes backend, because I use the bes viewer to check whether the logs are there. For bes I used the OSS buildbuddy docker container.

### Which operating system are you running Bazel on?


Linux

### What is the output of `bazel info release`?

Bazelisk version: v1.15.0
Build label: 7.0.1
Build target: @@//src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/bazel:BazelServer
Build time: Thu Jan 18 18:04:46 2024 (1705601086)
Build timestamp: 1705601086
Build timestamp as int: 1705601086

### If `bazel info release` returns `development version` or `(@non-git)`, tell us how you built Bazel.


_No response_

### What's the output of `git remote get-url origin; git rev-parse master; git rev-parse HEAD` ?


```text
https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_go.git
54c12e5d6bc591137ca9127a7629a8fc68ab6094
54c12e5d6bc591137ca9127a7629a8fc68ab6094
```


### Is this a regression? If yes, please try to identify the Bazel commit where the bug was introduced.


don't know.

### Have you found anything relevant by searching the web?

No

### Any other information, logs, or outputs that you want to share?

This could be nothing since I'm not very familiar with the bazel source code, but when I instrumented bazel to add logging for this bug, I could see the code path reached here: https://cs.opensource.google/bazel/bazel/+/master:src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/remote/ByteStreamBuildEventArtifactUploader.java;l=355

but never go to the bytestream grpc uploader here: https://cs.opensource.google/bazel/bazel/+/master:src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/remote/ByteStreamUploader.java;l=128;drc=aa6fa34f50b4fff74f9085fad76e34681dac3ecb?q=bytestreamgrpc&ss=bazel%2Fbazel

For some reason, [isRemoteFile](https://cs.opensource.google/bazel/bazel/+/master:src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/remote/ByteStreamBuildEventArtifactUploader.java;l=133-136) was returning true for the logs even though they are local files, which I suspect was causing bazel to not upload the logs.

On the second run, the uploads reach the bytestream grpc uploader and are successfully uploaded.
